Authors: Francesco H. Janzen, Julian Richard Starr
Title:
Continental drift, mass extinction, and the evolution of an
ancient lineage of freshwater fish (Osteoglossomorpha:
Actinopterygii).
Keywords:
adaptive radiation, continental drift, diversification
rates, fossil-calibration, key biological innovation, mass extinction,
Osteoglossomorpha, vicariance
Abstract:
Aim: A fundamental question in the field of biogeography
is how major natural phenomena have shaped diversification rates across
the tree of life. In this study, we seek to understand how mass
extinction and continental drift have influenced the evolutionary
history of the superorder Osteoglossomorpha, an early lineage of
freshwater teleost (bony) fishes. We predict that vicariance resulting
from continental drift will establish deep-node macroevolutionary
relationships, but that mass extinction will be followed by a rapid
increase in diversification due to a decrease in interspecific
competition.
